article_title: Changes in Baltimore Public Transportation in Wake of Riots
article_text:
BALTIMORE, MD - APRIL 27: Baltimore Police officers react to rocks that were thrown on Reisterstown Road near Mowdamin Mall, April 27, 2015 in Baltimore, Maryland. The funeral service for Freddie Gray, who died last week while in Baltimore Police custody, was held on Monday morning. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

A day after some protesters

turned to violence in Baltimore

, the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) announced several service changes for local transportation Tuesday.

Baltimore's Metro Subway is traveling to the Johns Hopkins station, but is bypassing the Mondawmin, Penn-North and Upton Market stops.

Local Bus is operating with several diversions, and the Mondawmin stop is closed.

Light Rail is operating on a regular schedule, as is MTA Mobility services, MARC Train and MTA Commuter Bus.

(Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)A day after some protestersturned to violence in Baltimore, the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) announced several service changes for local transportation Tuesday.
The funeral service for Freddie Gray, who died last week while in Baltimore Police custody, was held on Monday morning.
Light Rail is operating on a regular schedule, as is MTA Mobility services, MARC Train and MTA Commuter Bus.
Baltimore's Metro Subway is traveling to the Johns Hopkins station, but is bypassing the Mondawmin, Penn-North and Upton Market stops.
